intro: Pappobolus juncosae, commonly known as the marsh sedge, is a flowering plant belonging to the Cyperaceae family. It is characterized by its grass-like appearance, with narrow, linear leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in wet or marshy habitats, thriving in environments with consistent moisture. Its reproductive structures include spikelets that produce tiny, wind-dispersed seeds. Pappobolus juncosae plays a role in stabilizing soil in wetland areas and supports various insect and bird species.
